--- title: "Hands-on Exercise 5" author: "Brigitta Karen Tsai" date: "February 8, 2025" date-modified: "last-modified" execute: eval: true echo: true message: false freeze: true --- # Part 1: Creating Ternary Plot with R # 1 Getting Started ## 1.1 Install and Load R Packages ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} pacman::p_load(plotly, ggtern, tidyverse) ``` ::: # 2 Data Preparation ## 2.1 Import Data ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} pop_data <- read_csv("data/respopagsex2000to2018_tidy.csv") ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr} ``` Rows: 108126 Columns: 5 ── Column specification ──────────────────────────────────────────────────────── Delimiter: "," chr (3): PA, SZ, AG dbl (2): Year, Population ℹ Use `spec()` to retrieve the full column specification for this data. ℹ Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message. ``` ::: ::: ## 2.2 Preparing the Data Use **mutate()** to derive new measures **young**, **economy active** and **old** ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} agpop_mutated <- pop_data %>% mutate(`Year` = as.character(Year))%>% spread(AG, Population) %>% mutate(YOUNG = rowSums(.[4:8]))%>% mutate(ACTIVE = rowSums(.[9:16])) %>% mutate(OLD = rowSums(.[17:21])) %>% mutate(TOTAL = rowSums(.[22:24])) %>% filter(Year == 2018)%>% filter(TOTAL > 0) ``` ::: # 3 Plotting Ternary Diagram with R ## 3.1 Plotting a static ternary diagram Use **ggtern()** function from **ggtern** package to create a simple ternary plot ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} ggtern(data=agpop_mutated,aes(x=YOUNG,y=ACTIVE, z=OLD)) + geom_point() ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](Hands-on_Ex05_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-4-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: Now let's add colors to each category ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} ggtern(data=agpop_mutated, aes(x=YOUNG,y=ACTIVE, z=OLD)) + geom_point() + labs(title="Population structure, 2015") + theme_rgbw() ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](Hands-on_Ex05_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-5-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ## 3.2 Plotting an interactive ternary diagram The code below create an interactive ternary plot using **plot_ly()** function of **Plotly R** ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} # reusable function for creating annotation object label <- function(txt) { list( text = txt, x = 0.1, y = 1, ax = 0, ay = 0, xref = "paper", yref = "paper", align = "center", font = list(family = "serif", size = 15, color = "white"), bgcolor = "#b3b3b3", bordercolor = "black", borderwidth = 2 ) } # reusable function for axis formatting axis <- function(txt) { list( title = txt, tickformat = ".0%", tickfont = list(size = 10) ) } ternaryAxes <- list( aaxis = axis("Young"), baxis = axis("Active"), caxis = axis("Old") ) # Initiating a plotly visualization plot_ly( agpop_mutated, a = ~YOUNG, b = ~ACTIVE, c = ~OLD, color = I("black"), type = "scatterternary" ) %>% layout( annotations = label("Ternary Markers"), ternary = ternaryAxes ) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr} ``` No scatterternary mode specifed: Setting the mode to markers Read more about this attribute -> https://plotly.com/r/reference/#scatter-mode ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output-display} ```{=html}
``` ::: ::: Now you can interactively hover and see the value of each point # Part 2: Visual Correlation Analysis # 1 Getting Started ## 1.1 Install and Load R Packages ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} pacman::p_load(corrplot, ggstatsplot, tidyverse) ``` ::: ## 1.2 Import Data ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} wine <- read_csv("data/wine_quality.csv") ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr} ``` Rows: 6497 Columns: 13 ── Column specification ──────────────────────────────────────────────────────── Delimiter: "," chr (1): type dbl (12): fixed acidity, volatile acidity, citric acid, residual sugar, chlo... ℹ Use `spec()` to retrieve the full column specification for this data. ℹ Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message. ``` ::: ::: # 2 Building Correlation Matrix: pairs() method ## 2.1 Basic Correlation Matrix ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} pairs(wine[,1:11]) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](Hands-on_Ex05_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-9-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: Now let us build the scatterplot matrix for column 2 to 12 ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} pairs(wine[,2:12]) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](Hands-on_Ex05_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-10-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ## 2.2 Drawing the lower corner Since correlation matrix is symmetric, let us only show the lower half of the matrix using the code below. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} pairs(wine[,2:12], upper.panel = NULL) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](Hands-on_Ex05_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-11-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: Now let us show the upper half of the correlation matrix ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} pairs(wine[,2:12], lower.panel = NULL) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](Hands-on_Ex05_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-12-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ## 2.3 Including with Correlation Coefficients The code will show the correlation coefficient of the variables pair instead of a scatter plot. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} panel.cor <- function(x, y, digits=2, prefix="", cex.cor, ...) { usr <- par("usr") on.exit(par(usr)) par(usr = c(0, 1, 0, 1)) r <- abs(cor(x, y, use="complete.obs")) txt <- format(c(r, 0.123456789), digits=digits)[1] txt <- paste(prefix, txt, sep="") if(missing(cex.cor)) cex.cor <- 0.8/strwidth(txt) text(0.5, 0.5, txt, cex = cex.cor * (1 + r) / 2) } pairs(wine[,2:12], upper.panel = panel.cor) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr} ``` Warning in par(usr): argument 1 does not name a graphical parameter Warning in par(usr): argument 1 does not name a graphical parameter Warning in par(usr): argument 1 does not name a graphical parameter Warning in par(usr): argument 1 does not name a graphical parameter Warning in par(usr): argument 1 does not name a graphical parameter Warning in par(usr): argument 1 does not name a graphical parameter Warning in par(usr): argument 1 does not name a graphical parameter Warning in par(usr): argument 1 does not name a graphical parameter Warning in par(usr): argument 1 does not name a graphical parameter Warning in par(usr): argument 1 does not name a graphical parameter Warning in par(usr): argument 1 does not name a graphical parameter Warning in par(usr): argument 1 does not name a graphical parameter Warning in par(usr): argument 1 does not name a graphical parameter Warning in par(usr): argument 1 does not name a graphical parameter Warning in par(usr): argument 1 does not name a graphical parameter Warning in par(usr): argument 1 does not name a graphical parameter Warning in par(usr): argument 1 does not name a graphical parameter Warning in par(usr): argument 1 does not name a graphical parameter Warning in par(usr): argument 1 does not name a graphical parameter Warning in par(usr): argument 1 does not name a graphical parameter Warning in par(usr): argument 1 does not name a graphical parameter Warning in par(usr): argument 1 does not name a graphical parameter Warning in par(usr): argument 1 does not name a graphical parameter Warning in par(usr): argument 1 does not name a graphical parameter Warning in par(usr): argument 1 does not name a graphical parameter Warning in par(usr): argument 1 does not name a graphical parameter Warning in par(usr): argument 1 does not name a graphical parameter Warning in par(usr): argument 1 does not name a graphical parameter Warning in par(usr): argument 1 does not name a graphical parameter Warning in par(usr): argument 1 does not name a graphical parameter Warning in par(usr): argument 1 does not name a graphical parameter Warning in par(usr): argument 1 does not name a graphical parameter Warning in par(usr): argument 1 does not name a graphical parameter Warning in par(usr): argument 1 does not name a graphical parameter Warning in par(usr): argument 1 does not name a graphical parameter Warning in par(usr): argument 1 does not name a graphical parameter Warning in par(usr): argument 1 does not name a graphical parameter Warning in par(usr): argument 1 does not name a graphical parameter Warning in par(usr): argument 1 does not name a graphical parameter Warning in par(usr): argument 1 does not name a graphical parameter Warning in par(usr): argument 1 does not name a graphical parameter Warning in par(usr): argument 1 does not name a graphical parameter Warning in par(usr): argument 1 does not name a graphical parameter Warning in par(usr): argument 1 does not name a graphical parameter Warning in par(usr): argument 1 does not name a graphical parameter Warning in par(usr): argument 1 does not name a graphical parameter Warning in par(usr): argument 1 does not name a graphical parameter Warning in par(usr): argument 1 does not name a graphical parameter Warning in par(usr): argument 1 does not name a graphical parameter Warning in par(usr): argument 1 does not name a graphical parameter Warning in par(usr): argument 1 does not name a graphical parameter Warning in par(usr): argument 1 does not name a graphical parameter Warning in par(usr): argument 1 does not name a graphical parameter Warning in par(usr): argument 1 does not name a graphical parameter Warning in par(usr): argument 1 does not name a graphical parameter ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](Hands-on_Ex05_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-13-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: # 3 Visualising Correlation Matrix: ggcorrmat() There are 3 R Packages that provide the functions to plot correlation matrix: 1. corrgram 2. ellipse 3. corrplot This section will cover ggcorrmat() from **ggstatsplot** package ## 3.1 The Basic Plot ::: panel-tabset ### Basic Code ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} ggstatsplot::ggcorrmat( data = wine, cor.vars = 1:11) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](Hands-on_Ex05_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-14-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ### Statistical Report ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} ggstatsplot::ggcorrmat( data = wine, cor.vars = 1:11, ggcorrplot.args = list(outline.color = "black", hc.order = TRUE, tl.cex = 10), ggplot.component = list( theme(text=element_text(size=3), axis.text.x = element_text(size = 7), axis.text.y = element_text(size = 7))), title = "Correlogram for wine dataset", subtitle = "Four pairs are no significant at p < 0.05" ) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](Hands-on_Ex05_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-15-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ::: - **cor.vars** is used to compute the correlation matrix needed to build the corrgram - **ggcorrplot.args** provides additional (aesthetics) to be passed to ggcorrplot::ggcorrplot function. The list should avoid the following arguments since they are already being used internally: **corr, method, p.mat, sig.level, ggtheme, colors, lab, pch, legend.title, digits.** # 4 Building Multiple Plots ggstatsplot supports faceting, but the feature is not available in ggcorrmat(), but in the **grouped_ggcorrmat()** function of **ggstatsplot** ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} grouped_ggcorrmat( data = wine, cor.vars = 1:11, grouping.var = type, type = "robust", p.adjust.method = "holm", plotgrid.args = list(ncol = 2), ggcorrplot.args = list(outline.color = "black", hc.order = TRUE, tl.cex = 10), annotation.args = list( tag_levels = "a", title = "Correlogram for wine dataset", subtitle = "The measures are: alcohol, sulphates, fixed acidity, citric acid, chlorides, residual sugar, density, free sulfur dioxide and volatile acidity", caption = "Dataset: UCI Machine Learning Repository" ) ) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](Hands-on_Ex05_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-16-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: # 5 Visualising Correlation Matrix using corrplot Package ## 5.1 Getting Started with corrplot ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} wine.cor <- cor(wine[, 1:11]) ``` ::: Use **corrplot()** to plot the corrgram ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} corrplot(wine.cor) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](Hands-on_Ex05_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-18-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ## 5.2 Working with Visual Geometrics In **corrplot** package, there are seven visual geometrics (parameter method) can be used to encode the attribute values. They are: circle, square, ellipse, number, shade, color and pie. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} corrplot(wine.cor, method = "ellipse") ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](Hands-on_Ex05_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-19-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ## 5.3 Working with Layout **corrplot()** supports 3 layout types: **full, upper** or **lower** ::: panel-tabset ### Basic Layout ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} corrplot(wine.cor, method = "ellipse", type="lower") ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](Hands-on_Ex05_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-20-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ### Customised ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} corrplot(wine.cor, method = "ellipse", type="lower", diag = FALSE, tl.col = "black") ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](Hands-on_Ex05_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-21-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ::: ## 5.4 Working with Mixed Layout ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} corrplot.mixed(wine.cor, lower = "ellipse", upper = "number", tl.pos = "lt", diag = "l", tl.col = "black") ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](Hands-on_Ex05_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-22-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ## 5.5 Combining corrgram with the Significant Test Using the corrplot package, we can use **cor.mtest()** to compute p-values and confidence interval of each pair of variables. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} wine.sig = cor.mtest(wine.cor, conf.level= .95) ``` ::: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} corrplot(wine.cor, method = "number", type = "lower", diag = FALSE, tl.col = "black", tl.srt = 45, p.mat = wine.sig$p, # use the p-value computation here sig.level = .05) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](Hands-on_Ex05_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-24-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ## 5.6 Reorder a corrgram Matrix reordering is important for mining the hidden structure and pattern in a corrgram. There are 4 supported sorting methods: 1. **AOE** is for the angular order 2. **FPC** is for first principal component order 3. **hclust** is for hierarchical clustering order, **hclust.method** for the agglomeration method to be used: - **hclust.method** should be one of **ward, single, complete, average, mcquitty, median,** or **centroid** 4. **alphabet** for alphabetical order ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} corrplot.mixed(wine.cor, lower = "ellipse", upper = "number", tl.pos = "lt", diag = "l", order="AOE", tl.col = "black") ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](Hands-on_Ex05_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-25-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ## 5.7 Reordering a correlation matrix using hclust ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} corrplot(wine.cor, method = "ellipse", tl.pos = "lt", tl.col = "black", order="hclust", hclust.method = "ward.D", addrect = 3) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](Hands-on_Ex05_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-26-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: # Part 3: Heatmap for Visualising and Analysing Multivariate Data # 1 Getting Started ## 1.1 Install and Load Packages ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} pacman::p_load(seriation, dendextend, heatmaply, tidyverse) ``` ::: ## 1.2 Import Data ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} wh <- read_csv("data/WHData-2018.csv") ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr} ``` Rows: 156 Columns: 12 ── Column specification ──────────────────────────────────────────────────────── Delimiter: "," chr (2): Country, Region dbl (10): Happiness score, Whisker-high, Whisker-low, Dystopia, GDP per capi... ℹ Use `spec()` to retrieve the full column specification for this data. ℹ Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message. ``` ::: ::: ## 1.3 Data Preparation Change the rows by country name instead of row number ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} row.names(wh) <- wh$Country ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr} ``` Warning: Setting row names on a tibble is deprecated. ``` ::: ::: ## 1.4 Transforming the dataframe into a matrix ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} wh1 <- dplyr::select(wh, c(3, 7:12)) wh_matrix <- data.matrix(wh) ``` ::: # 2 Static Heatmap
